author: By Cecilia Kang, David McCabe and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Tech Giants, Fearful of Proposals to Curb Them, Blitz Washington With Lobbying
description: Executives, lobbyists, and more than a dozen groups paid by Big Tech have tried to head off bipartisan support for six bills meant to undo the dominance of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google.
content: WASHINGTON — In the days after lawmakers introduced legislation that could break the dominance of tech companies, Apple’s chief executive, Tim Cook, called Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other members of Congress to deliver a warning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: Billie Eilish Apologizes for Lip-Syncing Anti-Asian Slur
description: The singer wrote on Instagram that she is “appalled and embarrassed.”
content: Billie Eilish, the 19-year-old Grammy-winning singer-songwriter, apologized on Monday after a years-old clip of her lip-syncing an anti-Asian slur surfaced on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: Behind One Pulitzer, Hundreds of Hands
description: When The New York Times was honored with the prestigious prize in the category of public service for its coverage of the coronavirus pandemic, it reflected the contributions of the entire newsroom.
content: This month, from a steep red staircase overlooking The New York Times’s newsroom, Dean Baquet, the executive editor, announced that the staff had won the Pulitzer Prize for public service for its coverage of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: A Race ‘Report Card’ Measures Whether the Music Industry Changed
description: The Black Music Action Coalition issued a 37-page report examining if powerful companies followed through on diversity commitments made last summer.
content: A new “report card” on race in the music business takes many of the industry’s most powerful companies to task, urging them to follow through on diversity commitments made last summer amid nationwide protests over the murder of George Floyd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Katz, Sarah Kliff and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: New Drug Could Cost the Government as Much as It Spends on NASA
description: The Alzheimer’s treatment will cost $56,000 per patient, and millions may use it. The result: “crazy numbers” for Medicare.
content: A newly approved drug to treat Alzheimer’s disease is expected to become a multibillion dollar expense for Medicare. By one projection, spending on the drug for Medicare’s patients could end up being higher than the budgets for the Environmental Protection Agency or NASA.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Tsui
title: ‘You’ve got to have patience,’ Ray McGuire says.
description: Mr. McGuire, a former Citigroup executive, makes his final push, with a little help from his family and friends.
content: Ray McGuire, a former Citigroup executive, said on Tuesday morning that he had slept “maybe 15 minutes” the previous night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: Fluid race heads to a finish as voters choose a mayor to lead N.Y.C.’s comeback.
description: The heated primary race, in which the city is testing ranked-choice voting, is in its final hours.
content: As far as the eye could see, New York City was covered with Democratic candidates for mayor on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Beinart
title: The Vacuous Phrase at the Core of Biden’s Foreign Policy
description: All the talk about the “rules-based order” is just a way of sidestepping the real issues.
content: Anyone who slogs through the diplomatic verbiage generated last week by President Biden’s inaugural overseas trip will notice one phrase again and again: “rules-based.” It appears twice in Mr. Biden’s joint statement with Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, four times each in the communiqués the United States issued with the governments of the Group of 7 and the European Union, and six times in the manifesto produced by NATO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein
title: Texas’s governor calls a special session, renewing effort to pass G.O.P. voting restrictions bill.
description: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas on Tuesday called a special session of the Texas Legislature that will begin on July 8, a move that revives Republicans’ effort to enact what are expected to be some of the most far-reaching voting restrictions in the country.
content: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas on Tuesday called a special session of the Texas Legislature that will begin on July 8, a move that revives Republicans’ effort to enact what are expected to be some of the most far-reaching voting restrictions in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Brave Enough to Unearth What’s Buried’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: We met in the South at a Starbucks, where I made Hannah an iced tea. Trained to be friendly, I asked her questions. We started dating before I graduated high school. Just two young women from poor Alabamian families, figuring it out. It’s hard being gay in the Bible Belt, but you don’t notice peoples’ stares when you’re only looking at each other. Four years later, her mother and my parents didn’t attend our wedding. We didn’t care. We drank champagne and went to the local gay bar after, where we found peace, surrounded by queens and real family. — Patricia West
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: China’s Sun Yang Barred From Swimming for Four Years
description: A champion swimmer was suspended (again) for a violation of doping rules, but his four-year penalty will expire in only three.
content: Sun Yang, a three-time Olympic champion and one of China’s most celebrated athletes, had his eight-year suspension from swimming reduced to four years on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kravitz Hoeffner
title: Scott Stringer bumps elbows and shoots selfies with voters on the Upper East Side.
description: “I love when kids are fans of the comptroller,” the Democratic candidate for mayor said.
content: Fresh off a radio interview with 1010 WINS, Scott M. Stringer, the city comptroller, made his way to greet voters at a public school on the Upper East Side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race, Voting Rights, Carl Nassib: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas Martin
title: Sylvia Deutsch, a Force in New York City Land Use, Dies at 96
description: The only person to lead two city land-use agencies and the first woman to head each, she expanded housing opportunities and promoted a revitalized Times Square.
content: Sylvia Deutsch, the only person ever to head two of New York City’s most powerful land-use agencies, posts that she used to expand housing, promote entertainment in Times Square and usher in self-service gas stations, died on Monday in Monroe Township, N.J. She was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Google’s Internet Ad Dominance Draws Fresh E.U. Antitrust Inquiry
description: The bloc’s investigation, which takes aim at the heart of Google’s business model, is part of a push to regulate the world’s largest technology companies.
content: European Union regulators took aim at the heart of Google’s business model on Tuesday, announcing that the Silicon Valley giant is the subject of a new antitrust investigation for potentially abusing its dominance in the online advertising market to stifle competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Venus Lacks Plate Tectonics. But It Has Something Much More Quirky.
description: Scientists say giant slices of rock may move across the surface of Earth’s closest neighbor like pack ice floating in the sea.
content: Within the next decade or so, Venus will be visited by a fleet of spacecraft. This grand tour of the second planet, the likes of which hasn’t been seen since the Cold War, is being driven by the quest to solve a profound planetary puzzle. Earth and Venus are the same size, are right next to each other and are made of the same star stuff. But Earth became an oasis while Venus became an acid-flecked inferno. Why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, who endorsed Maya Wiley, says she ranked Scott Stringer second.
description: She also criticized Eric Adams, calling him “very Trumpian.”
content: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez endorsed Maya Wiley for mayor of New York City this month, helping to elevate her as the strongest progressive in the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: Can I vote today?
description: If you are a United States citizen who has been a New York City resident for at least 30 days, and are not currently incarcerated for a felony, you can vote today — if you registered by the May 28 deadline.
content: It might sound obvious, but the first step to voting in the New York City primaries is to make sure you are eligible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Carl Nassib, the First Openly Gay N.F.L. Player, Has Been a Football Everyman
description: “I’ve been meaning to do this for a while now,” the N.F.L. lineman said. He comes from a football family, was a standout at Penn State and has taught his teammates about personal finance.
content: Las Vegas Raiders defensive lineman Carl Nassib walked outside his home in West Chester, Pa., looked directly into his phone and did something that he said he hoped would one day no longer be necessary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: With eight million shots in a day, India tries to energize its vaccination effort.
description: As the country’s second Covid wave recedes, Monday’s  was the most Covid shots administered in one day in any country outside China.
content: India administered 8.6 million doses of Covid vaccines on Monday, setting a national record on the first day of a new policy that offers free vaccines for all adults and aims to energize a lackluster inoculation effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Want to Get Trump Re-elected? Dismantle the Police.
description: The Trump G.O.P.'s voter-suppression efforts and surging murder rates leave Democrats vulnerable.
content: Like everyone else, I look forward to a summer of reconnecting with family and friends and relishing a good ole Fourth of July barbecue — unmasked! But I will be doing so with a pit in my stomach, because just beneath the surface calm in America, volcanic forces are gathering that could blow the lid off our democracy. We are living in a fool’s paradise. Enjoy it while it lasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Democratic Group Will Pour $20 Million Into Voting Rights Efforts
description: Priorities USA, one of the largest liberal super PACs, is hoping to counteract Republican-driven voting restrictions through both digital ad campaigns and legal efforts.
content: Priorities USA, one of the biggest Democratic super PACs, announced on Tuesday that it would pump $20 million into voting rights initiatives ahead of the 2022 election cycle, aiming to combat Republican-led election laws with digital ads and organizing as well as in the courts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Eastern Europe’s troubled populist leaders.
content: A right-wing populist wave in Eastern European countries such as Slovenia, Hungary and Poland, lifted by Donald Trump’s 2016 victory, has met a serious obstacle: Its leaders are not very popular, in large part because of their response to the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Theater Heads North, and in Every Direction at Once
description: A psychological drama from Japan and a classic English comedy are among the high-contrast offerings in the Berkshires and Hudson Valley.
content: Theater is confusing this summer. As the return to live, in-person performance accelerates, many productions conceived under earlier limitations are emerging in a world that looks different than expected.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Sarah Schulman
description: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Sarah Schulman. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Sarah Schulman. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: ‘You have to win,’ a Bronx voter told Kathryn Garcia. ‘I’m working on it,’ she replied.
description: Ms. Garcia’s schedule was packed with visits to polling stations around the city.
content: Walking along Asch Loop in the Bronx Tuesday morning, Kathryn Garcia met a couple of voters with a message of their own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Primary Day in New York: Rain, Short Lines and a New Kind of Ballot
description: New York City voters used ranked-choice voting for the first time in a mayoral race on Tuesday, and many of them took it in stride.
content: Laura Benedek, 75, has not missed an election since she cast her first vote — for Lyndon B. Johnson as president. Seated in her wheelchair on Tuesday, outside her polling place on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, she flaunted her “I Voted” sticker.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Policing and the New York Mayoral Race
description: As voters head to the polls, we talk to two Democrats about an election that is testing the city’s values.
content: [Live election results in NYC]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Siberia’ Review: Beast of the Northern Wilds
description: Abel Ferrara’s latest psychodrama sends an ever-intense Willem Dafoe into the Arctic wilderness on a visionary reckoning with his memories and sense of self.
content: Everybody’s got a plan until a bear wallops them. That happens to Clint (Willem Dafoe) in “Siberia,” Abel Ferrara’s latest psychodrama, which is equally set in the snowy Arctic wilds and the desolate reaches of an unquiet mind. This bracingly pure dream journey starts with Clint as a frontier bartender in a cabin, serving the odd hunter or babushka, and follows him on a dog-driven sled chase through memories and visions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: I’ve Cracked Zodiac, a French Engineer Says. Online Sleuths Are Skeptical.
description: Fayçal Ziraoui caused an online uproar after saying he had cracked unsolved ciphers attributed to the Zodiac killer in California and identified him, potentially ending a 50-year-old quest.
content: ARGENTEUIL, France — Fayçal Ziraoui loves a good challenge. As a teenager, he designed 3-D animations. In 2018, he completed an Ironman race. More recently, he developed virtual reality software that allows people to experience life in a space capsule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Should I Hang Out With Someone Whose Political Views I Hate?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether it’s hypocritical for a liberal to socialize with an increasingly extreme conservative.
content: I am a liberal in a blue city in a red state. One of my friends is married to a man who has become increasingly conservative over the past year (an “anti-Black Lives Matter, anti-abortion, Democrats are all idiots and socialists are taking over the country” mind-set), and his posts on social media are becoming more and more extreme. We occasionally socialize as couples. When we are together, I am friendly with him, and we avoid overt political talk, but as his social media becomes more and more extreme, I feel conflicted about continuing to accept invitations to socialize with them. Is it hypocritical of me to socialize with them when I find his personal political views so abhorrent? Name Withheld.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Adams Leads in N.Y.C. Mayoral Primary, but Ranked-Choice Awaits
description: Voters on Tuesday took part in the city’s first mayoral election using ranked-choice voting, a system that may delay the declaration of a winner until mid-July.
content: Eric Adams, who ran for mayor of New York City on a message intensely focused on issues of public safety, emerged on Tuesday with a substantial lead in the Democratic primary, but fell well short of outright victory in a race that will now usher in a new period of uncertainty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Sounds a Lot Like You
description: Matt Frederick rocks out.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — This puzzle is a throwback! Matt Frederick makes his New York Times crossword debut with one from the vaults (or should I say, three from the vaults?), offering up a visual tribute to three classic rock bands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindy Hirschfeld
title: It’s Summer in the Ski Towns, 2.0
description: Last year, mountain resorts were overrun by travelers in search of space and fresh air. The visitors are expected back, but now the towns have expanded activities and plans in place to deal with the crowds.
content: For their vacation this summer, Susan Thomae-Morphew and her husband have booked a house in the small ski resort town of Red Lodge, Mont., with a group of friends. As they message daily about the trip, the anticipation grows, said Ms. Thomae-Morphew, a performing arts administrator in Tyler, Texas. “Being outside with friends is smart and renewing, and it feeds your soul,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Why the Hollywood Elite Are Giving to Los Angeles Schools
description: Tuesday: A group including George Clooney is set to start a film and television school in the city’s public school district.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Airlines Face a Bailout Backlash
description: They, and other companies that took pandemic rescue money, face new demands in return for their rescues.
content: American Airlines confirmed yesterday that, amid delays trying to keep up with surging demand, it would cut nearly 1,000 flights in the first half of July. Fewer flights, especially if other airlines follow its lead, would drive up ticket prices and force passengers to delay travel plans, which means less money flowing to travelers’ desired destinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Vora
title: An Architect With an Eye on the Environment
description: Increasingly, architects and builders are thinking about how their creations affect the health of the planet. Kunle Adeyemi has built his career around that question.
content: This article is part of a special report on Climate Solutions, which focuses on the changing relationship between the people and the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Maya Wiley reflects on being a role model for young girls: ‘It’s deeply moving.’
description: Ms. Wiley would be the first Black woman elected mayor of New York.
content: Maya Wiley spent Tuesday afternoon in Harlem hugging voters and stopping to take photos with children. She was losing her voice. It was raining on and off. But she was determined to finish the race strong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Kwak-Hefferan
title: How to Have the Hard Vaccination Conversations
description: Asking someone if they’ve had a Covid shot can be tricky. Here’s how to navigate the new norms of health disclosure.
content: Ashley Z. Ritter’s vaccination conflict came to a head in April. She’d hired a part-time babysitter for her three kids just as the family moved to a new home in Yardley, Pa., last August. The babysitter, Lauren Greenewald, helped manage virtual school for the two older children, 6 and 7, while also juggling the 2-year-old and working toward a master’s degree in school counseling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Three Out: Olympic Baseball Qualifier Won’t Have a Full Field
description: A last-minute move to Mexico created “insurmountable” challenges for Australia, Taiwan and China, leaving only three teams to play for the final spot in Tokyo.
content: For an Australian baseball player, reaching the major leagues in the United States is a rare achievement. Only 32 players born in Australia have done so, according to Baseball Reference, with Chicago White Sox closer Liam Hendriks serving as the most notable current player. But in a country where baseball isn’t a mainstream sport, reaching the Olympics is a more widely recognized feat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Judge narrows lawsuits over clearing of protesters before a Trump photo op.
description: The judge said that federal officials had immunity, and that claims of a conspiracy to clear Lafayette Square for President Donald J. Trump’s walk across it were “simply too speculative.”
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Monday partly dismissed claims filed by Black Lives Matter, the American Civil Liberties Union and others accusing the Trump administration of abusing its power to violently disperse a protest outside the White House last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $3.75 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Did the Coronavirus Come From a Lab?
description: 18 months after the virus emerged, we still don’t know its origin story.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Skewers Trump’s Covid Response
description: Colbert joked on Monday night about a forthcoming book on the former president’s pandemic plan: “The main detail: There wasn’t one.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Looking for more to watch? Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Appeals Court Blocks Ruling That Overturned California’s Assault Weapons Ban
description: The decision by a three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit leaves the three-decade-old ban in place while litigation continues.
content: A federal appeals court on Monday put a hold on a federal judge’s ruling that overturned California’s 32-year-old ban on assault weapons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Vaez and Dina Esfandiary
title: The Hard-Liners Won in Iran. That’s Not All Bad News.
description: A more monolithic Iranian system that seeks stability presents Washington with an opportunity.
content: The conventional wisdom in Washington is that Iran’s elections are insignificant. Regardless of who wins, the argument goes, in the end, it’s the supreme leader who calls the shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: ‘Glove, Hat and Belt’: M.L.B. Begins a New Era of Enforcement
description: Jacob deGrom was the first pitcher inspected as part of baseball’s crackdown on foreign substances. It did not stop him from dominating Atlanta.
content: Let the record show that Jacob deGrom was the first pitcher subjected to a mandatory search by umpires under Major League Baseball’s new police state. The league decided to start with the best on Monday and work its way down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Covid Surge in Africa Raises Fears of a Calamity Like India’s
description: The pandemic is worsening in Africa as more contagious variants spread, vaccinations lag and hospitals in some places are pushed beyond their limits.
content: KISUMU, Kenya — Before Kenya’s president and other leaders arrived in late May to mark a major public holiday, health officials in Kisumu on Lake Victoria saw disaster brewing. Coronavirus infections were spiking, hospital isolation units were filling up and the highly contagious Delta variant had been found in Kenya for the first time — in Kisumu County.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Primary Day Is Finally Here
description: What to expect to see on your ballot, and how to navigate ranked-choice voting.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: How an Anti-Corruption Bill Became a Showdown on Democracy
description: The filibuster of a sprawling bill on voter rights, corruption and campaign finance caps its journey from a Democratic statement to a larger struggle over the nation’s direction.
content: WASHINGTON — When House Democrats sat down to write an expansive elections and presidential ethics bill in 2019, passage was the farthest thing from their minds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Andrew Yang gets an early start.
description: “It’s Election Day! Yeah!” Mr. Yang said, clapping and pumping his fists as he talked to reporters. “And I think you know who they’re voting for — this guy!”
content: The sun had been up for only an hour, a meager press corps had just rolled out of bed, and there were just a handful of voters to greet at the polling place in Chelsea that was Andrew Yang’s first stop on Tuesday. None of this curtailed his enthusiasm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra March
title: We Were Promised a Village: A Year in the Life of Pandemic-Baby Parents
description: Readers share life lessons from an extraordinary year.
content: On March 7, 2020, Gov. Andrew Cuomo declared a state of emergency in New York in the face of rapidly rising Covid-19 cases. Three months and one day later, my daughter was born. I had waited so long to meet her, but when the doctors placed her on my chest and I tilted my head to see her, the mask I was wearing obscured the view of her tiny features. That was the first of many times that the pandemic slipped a veil between our new child and the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Wright-Piersanti
title: Change Comes to the N.C.A.A.
description: A Supreme Court ruling has opened the door to a new era in college sports.
content: In a unanimous ruling yesterday, the Supreme Court said that the N.C.A.A., which governs college sports, could not prohibit student-athletes from receiving modest, education-related payments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Richard Stolley, Founding Editor of People Magazine, Dies at 92
description: He also scored a major journalistic coup by securing the rights to the Zapruder film of John F. Kennedy’s assassination for Life magazine.
content: Richard B. Stolley, the founding editor of People magazine, which changed the course of American publishing with its personality-driven approach to journalism and which has long been one of the most successful magazines in the nation’s history, died on June 16 at a hospital in Evanston, Ill. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: A lack of exit polls makes it even harder to figure out who’s ahead.
description: A source of election-night information valued by media outlets and political junkies alike is unlikely to be available for this race.
content: To the many things that distinguish this Democratic primary for mayor from the last, add one more: There is likely to be no public exit polling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: They Voted for Brexit, but Not the Giant Truck Park That Came With It
description: Yet even that floodlit eyesore near a formerly idyllic village in southeast England has not altered local views on the split with the E.U.
content: MERSHAM, England — Since work began on a post-Brexit border checkpoint, villagers nearby have complained of construction noise, a cloud of dust, damage to their homes, unsavory refuse and giant trucks blasting their horns at night and getting stranded on tiny rural roads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: The Delta Variant: What Scientists Know
description: The variant is gaining traction worldwide. But vaccines are driving down coronavirus case numbers in the U.S., and it’s unclear whether Delta will reverse that trend.
content: The super-contagious Delta variant of the coronavirus is now responsible for about one in every five Covid-19 cases in the United States, and its prevalence has doubled in the last two weeks, health officials said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: The Teamsters consider a new emphasis on organizing Amazon workers.
description: Delegates will vote on a resolution pledging “all resources necessary” for efforts to unionize the retail giant.
content: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which represents over one million workers in North America in industries including parcel delivery and freight, will vote on whether to make it a priority to organize Amazon workers and help them win a union contract.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Munich Wanted to Light Its Stadium in a Pride Rainbow. European Soccer Said No.
description: The lighting plan was meant as a statement against a new law in Hungary, whose team is taking on Germany on Wednesday. UEFA said the request was too political.
content: BERLIN — Europe’s governing soccer body refused on Tuesday a request by Munich to illuminate its stadium in the rainbow colors of the Pride flag when Germany meets Hungary in the European soccer championship — an act proposed to protest a recent Hungarian law that critics say is being used to target the L.G.B.T. community.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Why Are the Games Still Happening? These Numbers Explain It.
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 22, 2021.
content: “We’re finally allowed to have that excitement, and I’m just giddy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saiyna Bashir, Zia ur-Rehman and Mike Ives
title: First They Lace Up Their Skates. Then They Fight Terrorism.
description: The police in Karachi, Pakistan, put 20 officers on in-line skates for counterterrorism patrols and to soften the force’s image. Critics call it a publicity stunt.
content: KARACHI, Pakistan — Syeda Aiman has learned to shoot while she skates. She isn’t a hockey player, but an officer on a counterterrorism unit in Pakistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Augustin
title: Cuba reports a high success rate for its homegrown Abdala vaccine.
description: Rather than rely on imports, the Caribbean nation bet on being able to develop and produce its own coronavirus vaccines, the smallest country to do so.
content: Cuba began its Covid-19 mass vaccination campaign more than a month ago with homegrown, unproven vaccines, wagering that they would prove effective enough to blunt the rapid spread of the coronavirus on the cash-strapped Caribbean island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: With Mass Vaccination Sites Winding Down, It’s All About the ‘Ground Game’
description: The shift away from high-volume centers is an acknowledgment of the harder road ahead: a highly targeted push, akin to get-out-the-vote efforts, to persuade the reluctant to get shots.
content: NEWARK — There were only six tiny vials of coronavirus vaccine in the refrigerator, one Air Force nurse on duty and a trickle of patients on Saturday morning at a federally run mass vaccination site here. A day before its doors shut for good, this once-frenetic operation was oddly quiet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino and Fatima Faizi
title: Attacked and Vulnerable, Some Afghans Are Forming Their Own Armies
description: With U.S. troops leaving, the Taliban advancing, and a steady collapse of security force bases and outposts, the Hazara and other ethnic groups in Afghanistan are raising militias.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The slaughter of students, mostly teenagers, at a tutoring center. The deaths of young athletes in a suicide bombing at a wrestling club. Mothers shot dead with newborns in their arms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A surge in Africa, and pandemic silver linings.
content: Africa is bracing for a wave of infections, driven in some places by the Delta variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Touring American Pop Music by Way of the Writers Who Have Addressed It
description: In “Songbooks,” the scholar and critic Eric Weisbard surveys music writing from the 1700s to today, with special attention to voices on the margins.
content: “How much history,” the critic Robert Palmer asked in “Deep Blues” (1981), “can be transmitted by pressure on a guitar string?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: When an Eel Climbs a Ramp to Eat Squid From a Clamp, That’s a Moray
description: Moray eels can hunt on land, and footage from a recent study highlights how they accomplish this feat with a sneaky second set of jaws.
content: In the video, forceps nudge a piece of squid that sits on a ramp as an offering. Suddenly, a snowflake moray eel named Qani heaves its muscled bucatini of a body out of the water and onto the ramp. It opens its mouth and bites the squid. The eel pauses a moment, opens its mouth again and, as if its tongue were a conveyor belt, sucks the squid even deeper into its mouth using a secret second set of jaws in its throat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: She Fought to Reopen Schools, Becoming a Hero and a Villain
description: The economist Emily Oster offers loads of data-driven advice about children and Covid-19. Many parents live by her words. Others say she’s dangerous.
content: Emily Oster, an economist at Brown University, has a lot to say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Euro 2020 Final Will Stay in London
description: An agreement to resolve a dispute about foreign visitors includes the news that a crowd of about 60,000 will be allowed for the final at Wembley Stadium next month.
content: The deciding games of this summer’s European soccer championship are staying in London after tournament organizers and the British government reached an agreement, ending speculation that England’s pandemic travel restrictions would prompt the relocation of the semifinals and finals from Wembley Stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Many Alzheimer’s Experts Say Use of Aduhelm Should Be Sharply Limited
description: Even those who supported the F.D.A.’s approval of the controversial new drug said authorizing it for anyone with Alzheimer’s disease was much too broad.
content: A new drug for the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease should be given to a much narrower group of patients than the federal approval permits, Alzheimer’s experts — including those who strongly supported approval of the medication — said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: They Relied on Chinese Vaccines. Now They’re Battling Outbreaks.
description: More than 90 countries are using Covid shots from China. Experts say recent infections in those places should serve as a cautionary tale in the global effort to fight the disease.
content: Mongolia promised its people a “Covid-free summer.” Bahrain said there would be a “return to normal life.” The tiny island nation of the Seychelles aimed to jump-start its economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Allen and Cari Sietstra
title: Miscarriages Are Awful, and Abortion Politics Make Them Worse
description: Restrictions on mifepristone mean patients are not getting the best treatment.
content: Up to 26 percent of pregnancies end in miscarriage. These losses can be as physically painful as they are emotionally wrenching. And yet many patients are not offered the best care for their miscarriages because of abortion politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Weiner
title: Meet Sydney Taylor, Unsung Creator of the All-of-a-Kind Family
description: Her books depicted a cozy Jewish family on the Lower East Side. In real life, her back story was more complicated.
content: FROM SARAH TO SYDNEYThe Woman Behind All-of-a-Kind FamilyBy June Cummins with Alexandra Dunietz
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni and Raymond Zhong
title: Bitcoin tumbles below $30,000 for the first time since January.
description: The cryptocurrency has erased nearly all of its gains for the year, a drop that came after China intensified it scrutiny of digital currencies.
content: Bitcoin fell below $30,000 on Tuesday for the first time since January after a torrid week of trading in which the cryptocurrency has lost nearly 30 percent of its value. The latest drop leaves the cryptocurrency little changed from where it began the year, erasing a large run-up in recent months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Neil Vigdor
title: 153 Texas hospital workers are fired or resign over mandatory vaccine policy.
description: The hospital employees had been suspended for two weeks for not getting vaccinated by the hospital’s deadline earlier this month.
content: More than 150 staff members at a Houston-area hospital were fired or resigned on Tuesday for not following a policy that requires employees to be vaccinated against Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Banks Slowly Offer Alternatives to Overdraft Fees, a Bane of Struggling Spenders
description: Aggressive overdraft fees are worth tens of billions of dollars a year to the banking industry. Account holders are finally getting some better options.
content: In less than a week, Keri Fitzpatrick, a self-described lunch lady, was dinged for $175 she definitely didn’t have.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: A Complicated Collaboration for a New ‘Enemy of the People’
description: Without seeing a script, Ann Dowd jumped at the chance to work with Robert Icke on his solo adaptation of the Ibsen classic. Then the debates began.
content: You are an established stage and screen actress, an Emmy winner with pivotal roles in two of the most critically acclaimed series of the past decade. One day, a young theatermaker rings with an offer you should refuse: a drastic remix of the Henrik Ibsen play “An Enemy of the People” as a solo show in which you would play all the parts. Oh, and he hasn’t written it yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Hill
title: Whenever She Has This Dream, Someone in Her Village Dies
description: Folklore informs Mariana Leky’s novel “What You Can See From Here,” which follows a motley cast of townspeople faced with a crisis.
content: WHAT YOU CAN SEE FROM HEREBy Mariana LekyTranslated by Tess Lewis
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Mobile-home owners fear evictions as pandemic protections end.
description: An estimated 22 million people in the United States live in mobile homes, which have evolved from travel trailers to structures that can be delivered by a truck.
content: An estimated 22 million people in the United States live in mobile homes, which have evolved from travel trailers to structures that can be delivered by a truck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: Spain Pardons Jailed Catalan Separatist Leaders
description: A major step toward defusing tensions in a conflict that has long divided Spain prompted mixed reactions from an independence movement.
content: MADRID — Spain’s government on Tuesday approved pardons to a group of separatists serving long prison sentences for their involvement in a failed attempt to form a breakaway state in the northeastern region of Catalonia, a major olive branch in a conflict that has long divided the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard
title: After voting, Eric Adams leans into his appeal to working-class New Yorkers.
description: “I slept like a baby,” he told supporters as he began a tour of Brooklyn neighborhoods.
content: By turns triumphant, teary-eyed and playful, Eric Adams — the Brooklyn borough president and retired police captain who has led the recent polls in New York’s topsy-turvy mayoral race — cast his ballot early Monday morning in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Big Impact of Small Changes
description: Only some of us are riding Peloton bikes and ordering food via app. But this can still disrupt everything.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Fire Destroys Two Catholic Churches on Canadian Indigenous Land
description: The fires come at a raw moment, just weeks after the discovery in British Columbia of the unmarked graves of 215 Indigenous children.
content: MONTREAL — National Canadian police were investigating on Tuesday after two century-old Catholic churches burned to the ground within hours of one another on Indigenous lands in British Columbia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Day, Samantha Stark and Joe Coscarelli
title: Britney Spears Quietly Pushed for Years to End Her Conservatorship
description: Confidential court records obtained by The Times reveal that the singer has urged changes to the arrangement that controls her life, and her father’s role in leading it.
content: In the years since a judge gave the father of Britney Spears broad control over her life and finances, concerned fans have questioned how the court could continue to deem her unable to protect and care for herself despite the fact that she was still a performing pop star.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Broadway’s ‘Music Man’ Names British Producer to Replace Rudin
description: Kate Horton will become executive producer of the show, which stars Hugh Jackman and Sutton Foster. It is scheduled to begin performances on Dec. 20.
content: A veteran British theater administrator will take over the day-to-day management of a starry Broadway revival of “The Music Man,” assuming many of the duties previously performed by Scott Rudin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariella Rudi
title: Three Hollywood Stars Recast Their Lives Deep in the Heart of Texas
description: As the pandemic upended Tinseltown, Jamie-Lynn Sigler, Haylie Duff and Becca Tobin made a pact to abandon Los Angeles and join the mass migration from California to Texas.
content: During the blockbuster plot twist that was 2020, three Los Angeles-based actors and longtime friends wrote themselves a scene that was playing out in cities across the United States. Early into lockdown, Becca Tobin, best known for her role as Kitty Wilde on the Fox series “Glee,” formed a pandemic pod with her fellow actors Haylie Duff and Jamie-Lynn Sigler, gathering for regular backyard confabs about shifting priorities, family demands and their future in Hollywood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: A Los Angeles Tech Flex
description: LA Tech Week was a vivid picture of the city opening back up and a reminder that Silicon Valley is no longer the only game in town.
content: LOS ANGELES — On Saturday evening, over 250 people crowded into a midcentury modern mansion in the Hollywood Hills for a party at the end of LA Tech Week, a six-day event series held across the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Ei-ichi Negishi, Nobel Prize Winner in Chemistry, Dies at 85
description: His work in creating a method to build complex organic molecules applied to everything from pharmaceutical manufacturing to electronics.
content: Ei-ichi Negishi, who shared the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2010 for developing techniques now ubiquitous in the manufacture of pharmaceuticals, died on June 6 in Indianapolis. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Resistance Fighters Battle Myanmar’s Military in Mandalay
description: A shootout in Myanmar’s second-biggest city was the first time the military and a group of armed civilians known as the People’s Defense Force clashed in a major urban area.
content: The gunfire in the city of Mandalay began shortly after 7 a.m. on Tuesday, as Buddhist monks paced the streets for alms and residents lined up for breakfasts of milk tea or noodle soup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: The Senate confirms Kiran Ahuja, Biden’s nominee to run the Office of Personnel Management.
description: Ms. Ahuja returns to the personnel agency where she served as chief of staff during the final two years of the Obama administration.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris cast the tiebreaking vote to confirm President Biden’s nominee to run the Office of Personnel Management, Kiran Ahuja, overcoming Republican objections to her nomination that centered on her views on racial justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Hua
title: The Best Way to Clean Your Ears: With a Spoon
description: Doctors strongly discourage people from scraping inside their ears. But knowing better and doing it anyway is part of what makes us human.
content: When I was growing up in the suburbs east of San Francisco, our teachers used to say, “Don’t put anything in your ear except for your elbow.” No matter how much our ears itched, we were told, we shouldn’t poke in a pen cap, the pink eraser on a No. 2 pencil or a cotton swab; doing so risked puncturing our eardrums.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New & Noteworthy Poetry, From First Peoples to Posthumous Ashbery
description: A selection of recent poetry titles of note; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
content: WOLF LAMB BOMB: Poems, by Aviya Kushner. (Orison, paper, $16.) Kushner channels the prophet Isaiah, “lone / crooner in the wildnerness,” and recasts his “raving mad” vision for a post-9/11 age of terrorism and geopolitical conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: What if American Democracy Fails the Climate Crisis?
description: Ezra Klein and four environmental thinkers discuss the limits of politics in facing down the threat to the planet.
content: Of late, I’ve been obsessing over a single question: What if political systems, in the United States and internationally, fail to curb climate change?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Black Campus Police Officers Say They Suffered ‘Unbearable’ Racism
description: Police officers at the University of Washington in Seattle, regarded as one of the nation’s most progressive cities, said they were the target of racist insults and harassment.
content: SEATTLE — Earlier this year, as Officer Russell Ellis neared the end of his late shift at the University of Washington’s campus police department, one of his superiors offered him an energy drink. The sergeant was laughing, Mr. Ellis said, noting that the beverage was flavored like watermelon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Moshing in the Rain: The Tenuous Return of the British Music Festival
description: Spending three days camping at a muddy music festival is a British tradition. But event operators fear that few will go ahead this summer, despite a trial last weekend.
content: CASTLE DONINGTON, England — At 5 p.m. on Friday, a metal band called Death Blooms walked onstage in a field here and launched into a pummeling track to open Download Festival, Britain’s first large-scale music festival to take place since the Covid-19 pandemic began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Why the Best Gardens Have Something Extra
description: Accessories like garden ornaments, furniture and firepits can make a beautiful landscape even more appealing. Here’s where to start.
content: When you’re designing a garden, it’s natural to focus on what you’re planting. But flowers, trees and shrubs aren’t all there is to a visually appealing outdoor space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea to Washington: Timetable on Talks Is Up to Us, Not You
description: The country turned down an American offer to resume negotiations “without preconditions,” as  President Biden’s envoy visited the region.
content: SEOUL — North Korea said on Tuesday that the United States would face a great “disappointment” if it expected a quick resumption of  talks about its nuclear weapons program, offering a blow to a Biden administration envoy who had proposed a new round of negotiations.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What lumber can tell us about the economy right now.
description: The drop in lumber prices, as production ramps up and orders fall, gives credence to the argument that the rise in inflation is a result of mismatches in supply and demand.
content: Lumber prices soared over the past year, frustrating would-be pandemic do-it-yourselfers, jacking up the costs of new homes and serving as a compelling talking point in the debate over whether government stimulus efforts risked the return of 1970s-style inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Sarah Schulman’s Radical Approach to Conflict, Communication and Change
description: The writer and activist discusses ACT UP, Israel-Palestine and the dangers of consensus in political movements.
content: Sarah Schulman’s work — as a nonfiction writer, novelist, activist, playwright and filmmaker — confronts the very thing most people try to avoid: conflict. Schulman, far from running from it, believes we need more of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How We Talk About Race and Gender
description: The way some Americans talk about these issues is changing. We want to hear what you think about these changes.
content: Much has changed in a year of racial reckoning that followed the killing of George Floyd and other Black men and women at the hands of the police, even the words we use to talk about these issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: In the Philippines, Rodrigo Duterte threatens to jail those who refuse shots.
description: The country’s president called the current severe outbreak “a national emergency” in a TV interview that included an expletive-laced rant against those who chose not to get a vaccine.
content: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines has threatened to send anyone who refuses a coronavirus vaccine to jail, as the country grapples with one of the worst outbreaks in Asia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Rick Owens on Corrupting the Classics
description: The goth designer has developed a thing for distorting iconic shoes.
content: By now, Rick Owens has “corrupted,” as he puts it, several iconic shoe brands, breathing his weirdness into the safe and reliable designs of Birkenstock, Dr. Martens, Adidas and Converse. But one man’s corruption is another brand’s highly marketable collaboration, and Mr. Owens has grown to appreciate these partnerships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Senate panel discusses legislation on statehood for Washington, D.C.
description: Senator Tom Carper, Democrat of Delaware, pushed for the Homeland Security Committee to hold the hearing, just the second on the topic in the chamber’s history.
content: A Senate committee on Tuesday discussed legislation that would establish Washington, D.C., as the nation’s 51st state, after the House passed the measure along party lines earlier this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Bishops, Biden and the Brave New World
description: Why the divide between the church and Catholic Democrats will widen even if the push to deny the president communion fails.
content: For the past four or so decades, since soon after the first “test-tube babies” were conceived outside a human womb, scientists have followed the so-called 14-day rule, confining research on human embryos to their first two weeks of life, before various developmental milestones like the first signs of an emerging central nervous system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: At a Queer Theater Festival, the Plays Are Brazenly Personal
description: The Criminal Queerness Festival offers three works that address subjects including addiction, fluid identity and social change.
content: Dima Mikhayel Matta has written about her home city before with language like “In Beirut, the streets smell of jasmine and coffee, and the morning call to prayer mingles with church bells.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: A Gay N.F.L. Player Broke a Barrier. Will Others Follow?
description: The number of publicly out L.G.B.T.Q. athletes in men’s biggest pro leagues lags far behind that in women’s sports. Will Carl Nassib’s announcement change that?
content: Congratulatory posts flooded social media on Monday when Las Vegas Raiders defensive lineman Carl Nassib announced on Instagram that he is gay, becoming the first active N.F.L. player to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: Players of Asian Descent on the L.P.G.A. Tour Lift Silence on Racism and Sexism
description: The Women’s P.G.A. Championship this week in Atlanta, just minutes from the fatal shootings of six Asian women this year, has surfaced fears and feelings about what it means to be Asian in the United States at a time of pervasive discrimination.
content: ATLANTA — Players of Asian descent have won eight of the past 10 Women’s P.G.A. Championships, but there is nothing cookie cutter about the winners. They include Shanshan Feng of China, who has worn tailored cow pants to reflect her fun-loving personality, and Sung Hyun Park of South Korea, who had a Korean word on her bag that translated to “I am different.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: Here’s How New Yorkers Feel About Ranked-Choice Voting
description: New Yorkers are using a new voting system citywide for the first time, but in interviews, many seemed characteristically unfazed: “It’s real easy if people just learn how to read.”
content: A New York City mayoral race that began over Zoom during the height of the pandemic came down to street campaigning in its final hours on Monday, with as many as half a million voters preparing to cast ballots when polls open on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tell Us About Your Unexpected Pandemic Joys
description: We know this has been a traumatic time. But some good things came out of the upheaval, too.
content: The pandemic was awful. Almost everyone lost something — or someone. None of us can get back those long, scary months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Schneider
title: Craft Distilleries Aim to Make Whiskey an Experience
description: Despite the financial pain wreaked by the pandemic, the industry grew in 2020 as businesses moved tastings and other activities outdoors.
content: GETHSEMANE, KY. — As pandemic lockdowns closed businesses around the nation last year, craft distilleries braced for the worst. Their business, after all, was built on the intimacy of sampling spirits in person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Schweber
title: Curtis Sliwa, Republican candidate, campaigns on the liberal West Side.
description: Mr. Sliwa, a Republican locked in a two-man primary against the businessman-activist Fernando Mateo, shook hands and paws.
content: Walking down Columbus Avenue in a navy suit, a bright red tie and his trademark red beret, Curtis Sliwa was treated like the media celebrity that he is when he came to vote at 9 a.m. Tuesday on the Upper West Side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryce Covert
title: Biden’s Paid Leave Plan Is Years Out of Date
description: While the idiotic controversy over what constitutes infrastructure rages, the president should look to his former rivals to improve his family plan.
content: “No one should have to choose between a job and a paycheck or taking care of themselves and a loved one — a parent, spouse or child,” President Biden told Congress in late April. It’s a simple yet profound concept in a country that, unlike all its wealthy peers, doesn’t guarantee paid family leave. We’re also a country that invests so little in child care and early education that American parents, usually mothers, are frequently faced with an impossible choice between child care and career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: White House Says It Will Narrowly Miss July 4 Vaccination Goal
description: People ages 18 to 26 have been slow to get their shots, aides to President Biden said, ruling out the possibility of getting 70 percent of adults at least partly vaccinated by Independence Day.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House publicly acknowledged on Tuesday that President Biden did not expect to meet his goal of having 70 percent of adults at least partly vaccinated by July 4 and instead would reach that milestone only with people older than 26.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: John Paul Brammer Is Obsessed With Kate Bush
description: The very-online writer, whose “¡Hola Papi!” advice column recently became a book, talks about folding knives, chili sauce and “Hounds of Love.”
content: The writer John Paul Brammer was half-jokingly worried about seeming like a “capitalist pig” when sharing his favorite things, as he had originally just listed products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Garland Says Watchdog Is Best Positioned to Review Trump-Era Justice Dept., Not Him
description: The attorney general said that various inspector general inquiries would help uncover any wrongdoing and that he wanted to avoid politicizing the work of career officials.
content: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Merrick B. Garland backed away on Tuesday from doing a broad review of Justice Department politicization during the Trump administration, noting that the department’s independent inspector general was already investigating related issues, including aggressive leak hunts and attempts to overturn the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Johnson
title: How to Destroy a Village
description: Liang Hong’s “China in One Village” recounts the forces that are undermining rural areas, and the helplessness of the people who live there.
content: CHINA IN ONE VILLAGE The Story of One Town and the Changing World By Liang Hong
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: India gives 8 million shots in a day.
content: India administered 8.6 million doses of Covid vaccines on Monday, setting a national record on the first day of a new policy that offers free vaccines for all adults. Officials say all of India’s roughly 950 million adults could be fully vaccinated by the end of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Against Expectations, Southwestern Summers Are Getting Even Drier
description: The finding by researchers runs counter to a basic tenet of climate change — that warming increases humidity because hotter air holds more moisture. It’s also bad news for fire seasons.
content: The Southwest, already the driest region in the United States, has become even drier since the mid-20th century, particularly on the hottest days, according to new research.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein
title: Texas G.O.P. to Renew Voting Push as Abbott Calls Special Session
description: Gov. Greg Abbott, a Republican, was forced to call for the special session after Democratic lawmakers staged a walkout last month to temporarily foil a major G.O.P. voting restrictions bill.
content: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas on Tuesday called a special session of the Texas Legislature that will begin on July 8, a move that revives Republicans’ effort to enact what are expected to be some of the most far-reaching voting restrictions in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Why Geology Is Our Destiny
description: A visit to the renovated hall of gems and minerals at the American Museum of Natural History reveals how the cosmos works in the real world.
content: One day in October 1820 two young men, Elijah Hamlin and Ezekiel Holmes, were hiking on a hill in Maine called Mount Mica when they spotted a glowing, green stone on the ground. They picked it up and started to look for others, but darkness was falling. The next day it snowed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: The virus is ravaging Colombia, where the death toll surpassed 100,000.
description: The surge in the country has been steadily worsening since spring and less than 10 percent of its population is fully vaccinated.
content: Colombia, where a surging coronavirus and a dearth of vaccines have led to widespread protests, has surpassed 100,000 recorded Covid-19 deaths, just the 10th country to pass that milestone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Tony Awards Announce First Three Recipients
description: The Broadway Advocacy Coalition, “David Byrne’s American Utopia” and “Freestyle Love Supreme” win special Tonys.
content: The Tony Awards, long delayed by the pandemic, announced on Tuesday the first recipients, honoring the Broadway Advocacy Coalition, an organization started five years ago by a group of actors and others as a tool to work toward dismantling racism through theater and storytelling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Fresco by Scotto Reopens With Sidewalk Seating
description: A restaurant in the new Graduate Roosevelt Island, a retro cocktail bar in the West Village and more restaurant news.
content: This neighborhood restaurant, run by Marion Scotto, along with her children, Elaina Scotto, Rosanna Scotto and Anthony Scotto Jr., has emerged from its pandemic hiatus in good shape. (It was open briefly last fall for outdoor dining only.) It’s not your typical local spot — it’s been a Midtown Manhattan magnet for the worlds of television, fashion, business and politics since 1993 — and that it’s busy again is a healthy sign. Now, for summer and beyond, it has an alluring new look with sidewalk seating surrounded by verdant lemon trees for a hint of Capri. There’s also a new chef, Ben Kacmarcik, who was at Pastis. (In 2016, his Bourdainesque exposé, “A Kitchen Lost …: An Open Letter on the End of a Kitchen Era,” was published.) Some items he’s added to the three-course lunch ($39), four-course dinner ($84) and à la carte menus include a mozzarella tower, grilled Caesar salad, lemon primavera pasta, paccheri amatriciana, yellowfin tuna panzanella and a rainbow ice cream tower.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jakob Guanzon
title: Coming Home Is Anything but Easy in This ‘Millennial Noir’
description: Elias Rodriques’s debut novel, “All the Water I’ve Seen Is Running,” follows a young man searching for answers after the death of his high school flame.
content: ALL THE WATER I’VE SEEN IS RUNNINGBy Elias Rodriques
source.name: The New York Times

author: By MJ Franklin
title: Life Gets Hectic Fast for a Heroine and Her Newfound 12-Year-Old
description: The title character of Mia McKenzie’s novel “Skye Falling” wants to avoid chaos and human connection. Too bad for her.
content: SKYE FALLINGBy Mia McKenzie
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Emma Bubola
title: Vatican Expresses Deep Reservations Over Gay Rights Bill in Italy
description: The move prompted cries of political meddling from liberal politicians and gestures of gratitude from conservatives. A church historian called it “an unprecedented act.”
content: VATICAN CITY — The Vatican has expressed concerns to the Italian government about a gay rights bill working its way through Parliament, prompting cries on Tuesday of church interference from liberal politicians, gestures of gratitude from conservatives and renewed tensions in the historically complicated relationship of neighboring governments that both call Rome home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Branch
title: Lamps and Sculptures That Evoke New York City Skyscrapers
description: The designer Umberto Bellardi Ricci’s metal lighting and cement objects feel of a kind with the buildings outside his window.
content: “Architecture is all lights and shadows,” says the Italian artist and designer Umberto Bellardi Ricci, seated in his 1,100-square-foot studio, a white-walled loft that overlooks the Manhattan skyline from the 13th floor of a former storage facility in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Casting glimmers of light across the floor are a collection of simple twice-folded rectangular metal objects in varying scales: a trio of geometric polished steel structures the size of desk ornaments, a two-foot-tall bent sheet of brass atop a brushed aluminum base and a six-foot-long version of the same piece that can stand upright, hang horizontally along the wall or lie flat on the ground. These functional artworks, which conceal bulbs within their creases, make up a series of light fixtures that Bellardi Ricci titled “Mano,” the Spanish word for hand, because they each evoke an open palm protecting a candle flame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: Six moments that shaped the N.Y.C. mayoral primary.
description: Sexual assault allegations, an alliance between candidates, a tour of a contender’s basement apartment: the race for mayor has had no shortage of drama.
content: It might be inevitable in a contest with over a dozen candidates, but the Democratic primary for New York City mayor has been full of twists, turns, drama and recrimination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Muktita Suhartono
title: Thailand opens a holiday island to vaccinated tourists.
description: A pilot project dubbed ‘Phuket Sandbox’ allows travelers from some countries to skip quarantine, offering hope for a battered tourism industry.
content: Dreaming of golden beaches and the caress of tropical breezes? Then consider a holiday on the island of Phuket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Mobile Home Owners Fear Evictions as Pandemic Protections End
description: Many who have struggled to keep up with mortgage payments are at the whims of a few financing firms that dominate lending in this market.
content: For more than two decades, Kimberly Burnworth has lived in a mobile home in rural West Virginia on a tract her grandfather acquired in the 1960s. A single mother, Ms. Burnworth is paid by the government to be a caregiver to her 11-year-old son, David, who has muscular dystrophy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Billock
title: Want to Adopt a Pet? Prepare for a Full Background Check.
description: Overlong applications, home inspections and fecal samples from existing pets are all fair game in finding a cat’s or dog’s “forever home.”
content: When I decided to rescue a kitten last spring, I didn’t expect it to take nearly a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti, Julian E. Barnes and Michael LaForgia
title: Saudi Operatives Who Killed Khashoggi Received Paramilitary Training in U.S.
description: The training, approved by the State Department, underscores the perils of military partnerships with repressive governments.
content: WASHINGTON — Four Saudis who participated in the 2018 killing of the Washington Post journalist Jamal Khashoggi received paramilitary training in the United States the previous year under a contract approved by the State Department, according to documents and people familiar with the arrangement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Home sales are slowing as climbing prices and a shortage of houses limit buyers.
description: A spike in demand has exacerbated a shortage in available homes that was already problem before the pandemic. Economists don’t expect the dynamics to shift anytime soon.
content: Sales of homes in the United States fell for the fourth consecutive month in May as a sharp rise in prices and a shortage of houses for sale led to a slowdown in the market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Democrats Vow to Redouble Voting Push: ‘Today Is the Starter Pistol’
description: Even as the party’s sweeping elections bill was blocked in the Senate, Democrats and civil rights groups reaffirmed their resolve to fight for voting protections in Congress.
content: For many Democrats and voting rights groups, the failure to advance the party’s major elections bill on Tuesday felt like the arrival of the inevitable, the final thud of a tree crashing in the woods after wavering for months. And everyone heard it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Federal Reserve chair says the United States needs ‘more inclusive prosperity.’
description: Jerome H. Powell, speaking before House lawmakers, played down chances of economic overheating and emphasized the importance of full employment.
content: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said on Tuesday that the central bank was focused on returning the economy to full strength, and he emphasized that the Fed would be more ambitious and expansive in its understanding of what that meant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: A Truckload of Evidence: 42,000 Pounds of Pistachios Are Stolen in California
description: A man who worked for a trucking contractor was charged with stealing 21 tons of nuts from a pistachio grower, the Tulare County Sheriff’s Office said.
content: A California pistachio company was conducting a routine audit when it noticed something suspicious: About 42,000 pounds of pistachios — nearly enough to fill a truck trailer — were missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Suicides among post-9/11 veterans are four times as high as combat deaths, a new study finds.
description: An estimated 30,177 of those who served after the 9/11 terrorist attacks died by suicide, compared with 7,057 killed in war operations.
content: As the last remaining American troops prepare to depart from Afghanistan and Congress debates removing presidential war-making powers for the first time in a generation, there is a growing understanding that the veterans of America’s longest wars have a far greater risk of suicide and other mental health concerns than those who came before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Parker
title: Can Geometry Be as Soul-Stirring as Poetry?
description: In “Shape,” Jordan Ellenberg argues for the importance of geometry as the underlying structure of reality.
content: SHAPEThe Hidden Geometry of Information, Biology, Strategy, Democracy, and Everything ElseBy Jordan Ellenberg
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes, Farnaz Fassihi and Katie Benner
title: U.S. Blocks Websites Linked to Iran at Key Point in Nuclear Talks
description: Officials seized the domains of about three dozen websites just days after Iran elected a new, hard-line president, and at a critical moment in nuclear negotiations.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration blocked access on Tuesday to several dozen websites linked to Iran, American and Iranian officials said, just as negotiations to bring the United States and Tehran back into an international nuclear accord appeared to be nearing a final decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Albert
title: The House That Mouse Built
description: This young adult version of a Spanish folk tale redefines what picture books can be. Reader discretion is advised.
content: THE TRUE STORY OF A MOUSE WHO NEVER ASKED FOR ITBy Ana Cristina HerrerosIllustrated by Violeta LópizTranslated by Chloe Garcia Roberts
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Filthy Animals: Stories,’ by Brandon Taylor: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “Filthy Animals: Stories,” by Brandon Taylor
content: Lionel had been out of the hospital for only a few days when the potluck invitation came.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: French Fries and Chapli Kebabs, Hot From the Skillet
description: The Chapli & Chips halal cart in Queens specializes in Pashtun meat patties and hand-cut potatoes, both fried in quantities of sizzling oil.
content: You can go a long way in your life as an eater without questioning the widespread belief that a kebab is grilled meat or fish on a stick. If you are paying attention, you will eventually notice that for some kinds of kebab the stick is optional and for others it is entirely absent. But the grill, whether it is a tandoor, a hibachi, a campfire or a hulking stainless-steel gas-fired backyard monster with Wi-Fi-connected temperature probes, may still strike you as a constant, the common denominator of all kebab equations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Pogash
title: How Do You Move a 30-Ton Diego Rivera Fresco? Very Carefully.
description: Diego Rivera’s rarely seen “Pan American Unity,” which celebrates the Americas, has been carefully extracted from its home at City College and moved to SFMOMA.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — For decades the monumental 10-panel fresco by Diego Rivera depicting a continent linked by creativity has been mounted in the lobby of a theater at City College of San Francisco. There, somewhat tucked away from the art world, it has been cared for as a labor of love by a de facto guardian who has long dreamed of finding a way to allow more people to experience it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Photograph the Moon
description: Use a camera with manual controls and a zoom lens. When shooting something so far away, stability is essential.
content: “A cold, calm night is best,” says Tim Easley, an illustrator in London who recently self-published a book of his black-and-white photographs of the moon. “When it’s hot, the air kind of wobbles a bit and makes things blurry,” he says. Ever since childhood, Easley has been obsessed with all things space. But when it comes to turning his camera skyward, he concentrates on the moon; other celestial bodies are too small and hard to see in the middle of a light-emitting city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: Los Angeles Has a Housing Crisis. Can Design Help?
description: As Angelenos grapple with ways to address affordable housing, density and homelessness, a new architecture competition looks to low-rise solutions.
content: Can California’s biggest city — and possibly America’s least affordable one — redesign its way out of the housing crisis?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: Connecticut Legalizes Recreational Marijuana, With Sales Aimed for 2022
description: Legislation signed Tuesday permits the possession of up to one and a half ounces of cannabis and provides a clean slate for some with past convictions.
content: After years of failed attempts, Connecticut legalized recreational marijuana on Tuesday, laying the groundwork to direct cannabis revenue into communities of color that have long been targeted by policies criminalizing the drug.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: U.N. Says Great Barrier Reef Is ‘in Danger.’ Australia Bitterly Disagrees.
description: UNESCO has called on the government to quickly mitigate the effects of climate change on the natural wonder and tourist destination, but officials say they are already doing plenty.
content: The United Nations has recommended that the Great Barrier Reef be placed on a list of World Heritage sites that are “in danger,” prompting a fierce reaction from the Australian government, which defended its management of one of the country’s top tourist destinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: Many parts of the U.S. needed persuading to get vaccinated. Not South Texas.
description: While officials across the United States have offered free beer, concert tickets and millions of dollars in lottery winnings to encourage vaccinations, residents of the Rio Grande Valley in South Texas have needed little prodding. Exposure to death and disease has been enough incentive.
content: While officials across the United States have offered free beer, concert tickets and millions of dollars in lottery winnings to encourage vaccinations, residents of the Rio Grande Valley in South Texas have needed little prodding. Exposure to death and disease has been enough incentive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Spain Waits, Impatiently, for the Goals to Arrive
description: Spain is still wonderful at passing the ball. It is far less effective, at least lately, and especially at Euro 2020, at putting it in the net.
content: Elías Bendodo has the long and unwieldy job title of a man with too much on his plate. For the last three years, he has served as minister of the presidency, public administration and interior for the Spanish region of Andalusia. On the side, he acts as the local government’s spokesman, all while serving as president of the Málaga branch of the Spanish political organization Partido Popular.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: 7 U.S. Swimmers to Watch at the Olympics
description: The 50 pool swimmers representing the United States in Tokyo have nine individual Olympic gold medals and three silvers among them. Thirty-five will be making their Olympic debuts.
content: The 50 pool swimmers representing the United States in Tokyo have nine individual Olympic gold medals and three silvers among them. Thirty-five will be making their Olympic debuts.

title: A Cast Iron Master
description: Chapli & Chips, a halal food cart in Queens, gets a lot of mileage out of its blackened skillets.

title: ‘I Am a New York Story,’ Eric Adams Says After Casting Ballot
description: Eric Adams, a Democratic candidate for New York mayor, gave an emotional speech to supporters after voting in the primary election on Tuesday.
content: Eric Adams, a Democratic candidate for New York mayor, gave an emotional speech to supporters after voting in the primary election on Tuesday.

title: Love, Always
description: Bill and Doug reminisce about their journey together on Fire Island.
content: Bill and Doug reminisce about their journey together on Fire Island.

author: By Reuters
title: Senate Debates Voting Rights Reform
description: Senate Republicans on Tuesday used the filibuster to block a bill intended to overhaul elections throughout the country.
content: Senate Republicans on Tuesday used the filibuster to block a bill intended to overhaul elections throughout the country.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Powell Says Economy Is Rebounding
description: On Tuesday, Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, testified that gross domestic product was on track to grow at the fastest rate in decades while inflation rates in certain categories of goods and services were likely to decline as the recovery continues.
content: On Tuesday, Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, testified that gross domestic product was on track to grow at the fastest rate in decades while inflation rates in certain categories of goods and services were likely to decline as the recovery continues.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Editors’ Note: June 22, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, June 22, 2021.
content: A photo essay published on June 14 featuring aerial images of swimming pools was removed from our website.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Don’t Care if You Looked Sexy. If You Wore a Skirt That Day. It’s Not Your Fault.’
description: Readers are moved by a woman breaking her silence about a rape by a professional baseball player 18 years ago. Also: G.O.P. threats; books on paper.
content: To the Editor:
